review_title: no family life ,rubbish money,and no value of staff
pros: if its your first job in the care industry then its a good one as it shows what care can be like at its worse. the only other pro is experience
cons: constantly short staffed .often worked a ratio of 1  staff to 10 residents. Putting not only your self but also the resident at risk.sometimes they were more concerned what the family wanted to do  for example to get a resident out of bed when that resident did not want to get out, needs to be more person centred care.money is not good and is better else where. constant phone calls of can you come Add to dictionary 8 days straight then get the day off.i found it difficult to balance work and family. They expect so much from you for no reward and carers may be dog poop at the bottom of your shoe unless your care leaders or management then expect meals out  at xmas .its a shame as most of the care homes have a great work team but leave.Just saw the culture and values  when I worked in the home I'm all for multi nationals but surpised me when they took on a group of ten  from Europe who lived in the home they had no background in care and only 7 of them could speak English as all the residents was English this at times frustrated them and upset then as they could not understand them it also upset staff to as they were difficult to work with.

pros: I am a manager with the trust and I have worked for the company for 4 years now and they have been very supportive of me with personal matters in life. My home is a 60 bedded home and like all managers I will say I have the best team, but for me it's always about having the best team because we want the best care for our biggest priority our residents, who are all always number one in our eyes. Whilst working for the trust I have seen and supported a number of my colleagues to grow and develop within the trust and also supported a number of my own team to grow and develop within the home. There is excellent training programs available to everyone from your everyday mandatory training through to extra management training. This year for all care homes has been an extremely challenging year with ever changing processes, but despite all of these changes my team have continued to work extremely hard to provide our residents with outstanding care and I for one couldn't be prouder of them. So I would suggest to anyone if you are wanting to come and work for us get in contact we will be happy to help you, don't take some small negative comments as fact come and see for yourself. For now best of luck 😃
cons: I don't have any negative comments

pros: None at all, unless your trying to cripple yourself financially!
cons: A really shoddy outfit, can't recruit or retain staff - immediete signs that this company is naff, during my time there it was a revolving door of staff, some staying a little as a month. Could not recruit a line manager for 7 months then she'd left after three weeks, on occassions we had more area/regional managers on site then care staff. They did nothing but make unreasonable promises to the residents and families and when these promises couldn't be honored disgruntled residents and families would get agitated at the care staff. These managers were more concerned in trying to keep the residents families happy than the actual residents ( if they'd not already let them down ) and failing that if they did not have any family then their friends. This company does not pay you for your whole time working through a shift but pays the agency staff a higher rate and fully for their time. I was repeatedly underpaid and when I produced corresponding rotas and payslips ( evidence ) clearly displaying money owed they did nothing , I was refused a reference ( after being shafted out of owed wages ) In the space of a year I was interviewed at home by safegaurding authorities ( due to managment mistakes ) I was questioned and interviewed by Thames valley police and had to give evidence/statement in Oxford magistrates court due to the actions of a former colleague ( she had previous record criminal record ) why employ a criminal OSJCT? We had residents leave within in months of moving in also. 0 hrs contract , no overtime rate , don't pay wages owed , completely inept senior/management staff in conclusion a really nasty company!

pros: The residents and their family's were lovely and so warm and friendly, was a pleasure to support the residents and sad to leave them. That's all.
cons: First job in care 6 years ago. I am now a residential manager and reflecting back on this employment with horror knowing what I know now and how standards should be makes it even worse. I worked at a home in Stonehouse. Home very outdated and smelt vey strong of urine the minute you walk in, not pleasant for the residents. Interviewers didn't seem interested in me at all, basic questions, seemed in a hurry to get the interview over with. Got the job and first day no training, sat me infront of a computer in isolation for 2 days reading really unhelpful material. Shadowed a member of staff for a few hours then thrown in the deep end to get on with it as short staffed and a busy workload. Genuinely had no idea what I was doing and when I spoke up several times there was no support. Extremely ganged up staff, a big group that didn't like outsiders and would bully myself and 2 other new staff and look at you like dirt. Total lack of respect. Poor moving and handling practises, a box of slings lucky dip no moving and handling plans the staff would use slings far too big for the small resident and vice versa. 3 staff to a floor or 22 residents was a normal shift, totally unsafe and not person centered at all. Never seen management on the floor they hid in the office with a closed door policy. Had extreme anxiety going to work everyday and only lasted 3 months before getting a fantastic job at my current employer of six years. I only hope things have improved now 6 years on, and wish I spoken up about my concerns at the time but being my first job in care I thought it was normal. Low pay. No support. No review meetings or return to works. Nothing at all. Genuinely still traumatised from this experience. Residents that should have been 2 staff for personal care were classed as a 1, it was unsafe and unfair on the residents. I heard a few months after terrible accident happened and there was a big investigation into the home. During my time I realised the only career development would be if your face fit and you knew the big wigs personally. A few of the staff were really lovely and welcoming and so caring and resident focused they felt the same as me but got on with it as they had previous experience I miss them to this day.
